title: How to Fry Olives

steps.headline: Drain the olives and pat them dry.
steps.description: Pour the olives into a strainer or colander to drain the liquid. Pat them dry with a paper towel if they were jarred in anything other than oil. If your olives are not pitted, use a cherry or olive pitter to remove the pits. You can use unstuffed olives or, for extra flavor, purchase garlic-stuffed olives.

steps.headline: Mix ingredients for dredging in three separate dishes.
steps.description: Mix the flour, garlic powder, and chili powder together in one dish. Keep the eggs in a separate dish. Combine the breadcrumbs with the ground black pepper in a third dish.

steps.headline: Dredge the olives and heat the oil.
steps.description: While you dredge the olives, cover the bottom of a saucepan with 2 inches (5 cm) of oil and heat it to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) over medium-high heat. Roll the olives in the flour mixture first, in the egg second, and in the breadcrumbs last. Set the olives on a plate and give the coating a minute or two to dry before frying. Use a kitchen thermometer designed for frying that attaches to the side of the pan.

steps.headline: Fry the olives until they’re golden brown.
steps.description: Carefully use a slotted spoon to place half of the olives into the hot oil. Don’t drop them in, as this will splatter hot oil. Fry the olives until the coating is golden brown, or about 30 seconds to a minute. Increase the heat as necessary to keep the oil’s temperature constant. It might cool slightly when you add the olives.

steps.headline: Drain the olives and serve hot.
steps.description: Remove the golden brown olives from the oil and drain them on a cooling rack or plate covered with paper towels. Fry and drain the second batch. Arrange the olives onto a platter and serve them hot. Try serving the olives with cubed Manchego cheese and thin slices of serrano ham. Provide your guests with tongs or toothpicks to serve themselves the hors d’oeuvres.

steps.headline: Drain and dry the olives.
steps.description: Drain the olives with a strainer or colander. Pat them dry with a paper towel, unless they’ve been jarred in oil. If your olives aren’t pitted, pit them with an olive or cherry pitter.

steps.headline: Heat half of the oil and saute the olives.
steps.description: Get a large frying pan hot over medium-high heat, and add half of the 1/3 cup (80 mL) of extra virgin olive oil. When the oil is hot, add the rosemary and olives, and saute them for 3 to 4 minutes, or until the rosemary is crisp and dark green. Stir the olives and rosemary occasionally while they’re cooking.

steps.headline: Cool the olives, toss them with the remaining oil, and serve.
steps.description: Place the olives and rosemary in a serving bowl and let them cool for about 5 minutes. Toss the remaining extra virgin olive oil with the olives and rosemary until they’re evenly coated. Serve the olives warm, and place a serving spoon into the bowl so your guests can scoop the olives onto their plates.

methods.name: Fried Olives Stuffed with Blue Cheese

steps.headline: Drain and stuff the olives with the cheese.
steps.description: Drain the olives, pit them if necessary, and pat them dry with a paper towel if they were jarred in any liquid other than oil. Roll small amounts of blue cheese into narrow log shapes. Stuff each olive with a small cheese log.

steps.headline: Dredge the olives in flour, egg, and breadcrumbs.
steps.description: Place the flour, egg, and breadcrumbs into three separate shallow dishes. Dredge the olives in the flour first, then in the egg, and in the breadcrumbs last. Let them rest for a minute so the coating can set.

steps.headline: Heat the oil and fry the olives.
steps.description: Cover a saucepan with 2 inches (5 cm) of oil. Heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) over medium-high heat. Fry the olives until the coating is golden brown, or about 30 seconds.

steps.headline: Drain the olives and serve them hot.
steps.description: Use a slotted spoon to transfer the olives to a cooling rack or plate lined with paper towels. Let them rest for a few minutes so the paper towel can soak up the excess oil. Place the drained olives onto to a platter and serve them hot. Set a pair of tongs or a small glass jar of toothpicks next to the platter so your guests can serve themselves.

methods.name: Fried Olives Stuffed with Ham and Garlic

steps.headline: Pulse the filling ingredients in a food processor.
steps.description: Combine in the onion, garlic, ham, parsley, 2 tablespoons of olive oil, and cayenne pepper in a food processor. Pulse the mixture by turning the processor on and off in intervals of a few seconds. When the filling pureed, creamy, and smooth, transfer it into a pastry bag with a nozzle small enough to fit into an olive’s cavity.

steps.headline: Drain and stuff the olives.
steps.description: Drain and pat dry the olives if they weren’t jarred in olive oil. Pit them if necessary. Using the pastry bag, stuff each olive with the pureed filling.

steps.headline: Dredge the olives and get the oil hot.
steps.description: Cover the bottom of a skillet or saucepan with an inch (2 cm) of peanut or canola oil. While you dredge the olives, heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius). Dredge the olives in the flour, beaten egg, and breadcrumbs in that order.

steps.headline: Fry the olives, then drain them and serve.
steps.description: Divide the olives into at least 2 batches so you don’t crowd the pan. Fry them for about 30 seconds, or until the coating turns golden brown. Drain the olives on a plate or rack lined with paper towel, then transfer them to a platter and serve hot.

text: Deep Fried Green Olives Drain the olives and pat them dry. Pour the olives into a strainer or colander to drain the liquid. Pat them dry with a paper towel if they were jarred in anything other than oil. If your olives are not pitted, use a cherry or olive pitter to remove the pits. You can use unstuffed olives or, for extra flavor, purchase garlic-stuffed olives. Mix ingredients for dredging in three separate dishes. Mix the flour, garlic powder, and chili powder together in one dish. Keep the eggs in a separate dish. Combine the breadcrumbs with the ground black pepper in a third dish. Dredge the olives and heat the oil. While you dredge the olives, cover the bottom of a saucepan with 2 inches (5 cm) of oil and heat it to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) over medium-high heat. Roll the olives in the flour mixture first, in the egg second, and in the breadcrumbs last. Set the olives on a plate and give the coating a minute or two to dry before frying. Use a kitchen thermometer designed for frying that attaches to the side of the pan. Fry the olives until they’re golden brown. Carefully use a slotted spoon to place half of the olives into the hot oil. Don’t drop them in, as this will splatter hot oil. Fry the olives until the coating is golden brown, or about 30 seconds to a minute. Increase the heat as necessary to keep the oil’s temperature constant. It might cool slightly when you add the olives. Drain the olives and serve hot. Remove the golden brown olives from the oil and drain them on a cooling rack or plate covered with paper towels. Fry and drain the second batch. Arrange the olives onto a platter and serve them hot. Try serving the olives with cubed Manchego cheese and thin slices of serrano ham. Provide your guests with tongs or toothpicks to serve themselves the hors d’oeuvres. Pan Fried Olives with Rosemary Drain and dry the olives. Drain the olives with a strainer or colander. Pat them dry with a paper towel, unless they’ve been jarred in oil. If your olives aren’t pitted, pit them with an olive or cherry pitter. Heat half of the oil and saute the olives. Get a large frying pan hot over medium-high heat, and add half of the 1/3 cup (80 mL) of extra virgin olive oil. When the oil is hot, add the rosemary and olives, and saute them for 3 to 4 minutes, or until the rosemary is crisp and dark green. Stir the olives and rosemary occasionally while they’re cooking. Cool the olives, toss them with the remaining oil, and serve. Place the olives and rosemary in a serving bowl and let them cool for about 5 minutes. Toss the remaining extra virgin olive oil with the olives and rosemary until they’re evenly coated. Serve the olives warm, and place a serving spoon into the bowl so your guests can scoop the olives onto their plates. Fried Olives Stuffed with Blue Cheese Drain and stuff the olives with the cheese. Drain the olives, pit them if necessary, and pat them dry with a paper towel if they were jarred in any liquid other than oil. Roll small amounts of blue cheese into narrow log shapes. Stuff each olive with a small cheese log. Dredge the olives in flour, egg, and breadcrumbs. Place the flour, egg, and breadcrumbs into three separate shallow dishes. Dredge the olives in the flour first, then in the egg, and in the breadcrumbs last. Let them rest for a minute so the coating can set. Heat the oil and fry the olives. Cover a saucepan with 2 inches (5 cm) of oil. Heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) over medium-high heat. Fry the olives until the coating is golden brown, or about 30 seconds. Drain the olives and serve them hot. Use a slotted spoon to transfer the olives to a cooling rack or plate lined with paper towels. Let them rest for a few minutes so the paper towel can soak up the excess oil. Place the drained olives onto to a platter and serve them hot. Set a pair of tongs or a small glass jar of toothpicks next to the platter so your guests can serve themselves. Fried Olives Stuffed with Ham and Garlic Pulse the filling ingredients in a food processor. Combine in the onion, garlic, ham, parsley, 2 tablespoons of olive oil, and cayenne pepper in a food processor. Pulse the mixture by turning the processor on and off in intervals of a few seconds. When the filling pureed, creamy, and smooth, transfer it into a pastry bag with a nozzle small enough to fit into an olive’s cavity. Drain and stuff the olives. Drain and pat dry the olives if they weren’t jarred in olive oil. Pit them if necessary. Using the pastry bag, stuff each olive with the pureed filling. Dredge the olives and get the oil hot. Cover the bottom of a skillet or saucepan with an inch (2 cm) of peanut or canola oil. While you dredge the olives, heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius). Dredge the olives in the flour, beaten egg, and breadcrumbs in that order. Fry the olives, then drain them and serve. Divide the olives into at least 2 batches so you don’t crowd the pan. Fry them for about 30 seconds, or until the coating turns golden brown. Drain the olives on a plate or rack lined with paper towel, then transfer them to a platter and serve hot.

Pour the olives into a strainer or colander to drain the liquid.
Pat them dry with a paper towel if they were jarred in anything other than oil.
If your olives are not pitted, use a cherry or olive pitter to remove the pits.
You can use unstuffed olives or, for extra flavor, purchase garlic-stuffed olives.
Mix ingredients for dredging in three separate dishes.
Mix the flour, garlic powder, and chili powder together in one dish.
Keep the eggs in a separate dish.
Combine the breadcrumbs with the ground black pepper in a third dish.
Dredge the olives and heat the oil.
While you dredge the olives, cover the bottom of a saucepan with 2 inches (5 cm) of oil and heat it to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) over medium-high heat.
Roll the olives in the flour mixture first, in the egg second, and in the breadcrumbs last.
Set the olives on a plate and give the coating a minute or two to dry before frying.
Use a kitchen thermometer designed for frying that attaches to the side of the pan.
Fry the olives until they’re golden brown.
Carefully use a slotted spoon to place half of the olives into the hot oil.
Don’t drop them in, as this will splatter hot oil.
Fry the olives until the coating is golden brown, or about 30 seconds to a minute.
Increase the heat as necessary to keep the oil’s temperature constant.
It might cool slightly when you add the olives.
Drain the olives and serve hot.
Remove the golden brown olives from the oil and drain them on a cooling rack or plate covered with paper towels.
Fry and drain the second batch.
Arrange the olives onto a platter and serve them hot.
Try serving the olives with cubed Manchego cheese and thin slices of serrano ham.
Provide your guests with tongs or toothpicks to serve themselves the hors d’oeuvres.
Pan Fried Olives with Rosemary Drain and dry the olives.
Drain the olives with a strainer or colander.
Pat them dry with a paper towel, unless they’ve been jarred in oil.
If your olives aren’t pitted, pit them with an olive or cherry pitter.
Heat half of the oil and saute the olives.
Get a large frying pan hot over medium-high heat, and add half of the 1/3 cup (80 mL) of extra virgin olive oil.
When the oil is hot, add the rosemary and olives, and saute them for 3 to 4 minutes, or until the rosemary is crisp and dark green.
Stir the olives and rosemary occasionally while they’re cooking.
Cool the olives, toss them with the remaining oil, and serve.
Place the olives and rosemary in a serving bowl and let them cool for about 5 minutes.
Toss the remaining extra virgin olive oil with the olives and rosemary until they’re evenly coated.
Serve the olives warm, and place a serving spoon into the bowl so your guests can scoop the olives onto their plates.
Fried Olives Stuffed with Blue Cheese Drain and stuff the olives with the cheese.
Drain the olives, pit them if necessary, and pat them dry with a paper towel if they were jarred in any liquid other than oil.
Roll small amounts of blue cheese into narrow log shapes.
Stuff each olive with a small cheese log.
Dredge the olives in flour, egg, and breadcrumbs.
Place the flour, egg, and breadcrumbs into three separate shallow dishes.
Dredge the olives in the flour first, then in the egg, and in the breadcrumbs last.
Let them rest for a minute so the coating can set.
Heat the oil and fry the olives.
Cover a saucepan with 2 inches (5 cm) of oil.
Heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius) over medium-high heat.
Fry the olives until the coating is golden brown, or about 30 seconds.
Drain the olives and serve them hot.
Use a slotted spoon to transfer the olives to a cooling rack or plate lined with paper towels.
Let them rest for a few minutes so the paper towel can soak up the excess oil.
Place the drained olives onto to a platter and serve them hot.
Set a pair of tongs or a small glass jar of toothpicks next to the platter so your guests can serve themselves.
Fried Olives Stuffed with Ham and Garlic Pulse the filling ingredients in a food processor.
Combine in the onion, garlic, ham, parsley, 2 tablespoons of olive oil, and cayenne pepper in a food processor.
Pulse the mixture by turning the processor on and off in intervals of a few seconds.
When the filling pureed, creamy, and smooth, transfer it into a pastry bag with a nozzle small enough to fit into an olive’s cavity.
Drain and stuff the olives.
Drain and pat dry the olives if they weren’t jarred in olive oil.
Pit them if necessary.
Using the pastry bag, stuff each olive with the pureed filling.
Dredge the olives and get the oil hot.
Cover the bottom of a skillet or saucepan with an inch (2 cm) of peanut or canola oil.
While you dredge the olives, heat the oil to 350 degrees Fahrenheit (177 degrees Celsius).
Dredge the olives in the flour, beaten egg, and breadcrumbs in that order.
Fry the olives, then drain them and serve.
Divide the olives into at least 2 batches so you don’t crowd the pan.
Fry them for about 30 seconds, or until the coating turns golden brown.
Drain the olives on a plate or rack lined with paper towel, then transfer them to a platter and serve hot.
